title: 105_hr1730
content: OFFSET OF PAST-DUE STATE TAX OBLIGATIONS AGAINST OVERPAYMENTS. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to allow the offset of past-due, legally enforceable State tax obligations against overpayments. Upon receiving notice from a State, the Secretary can reduce overpayments to pay the State tax obligation. The Internal Revenue Code allows offsetting past-due State tax obligations against overpayments. The Secretary can reduce overpayments to satisfy State tax obligations, notifying the taxpayer of the reduction. If offsetting a joint return, the notice includes information for each filer. The Internal Revenue Code allows offsetting overpayments against past-due State tax obligations. The Secretary can apply overpayments to satisfy debts owed to Federal agencies or past-due support. If multiple debts are owed to State agencies, overpayments are applied in the order they accrued. The Internal Revenue Code allows offsetting overpayments against past-due State tax obligations. States must notify individuals of proposed actions, provide a 60-day period for evidence submission, consider evidence presented, and ensure validity of the determination made. For offsetting overpayments against past-due State tax obligations, the State must ensure the determination is valid and efforts were made to collect the debt. A past-due, legally enforceable State tax obligation is a debt resulting from a court judgment or administrative hearing, no longer subject to review. The Secretary will issue regulations for States to submit notices of past-due State tax obligations, including local taxes, that are legally enforceable and not delinquent for more than 10 years. The regulations will specify the types of State taxes and minimum debt amounts eligible for reduction procedures. The regulations may require States to pay a fee to reimburse the Secretary for the cost of applying the reduction procedure. Any fee paid shall be used to reimburse appropriations that bore the cost. States receiving notice of an erroneous payment must promptly pay the Secretary the amount. The tax code is being amended to allow disclosure of certain information to states requesting refund offsets for past-due state tax obligations. Conforming amendments are also being made to sections related to overpayments and reductions. The tax code is being amended to allow disclosure of information to states for refund offsets related to past-due state tax obligations. Amendments are made to sections concerning overpayments and reductions, including changes to subsections (f) and (h) of section 6402. Amendments also apply after technical corrections to the Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996. The tax code is being amended to allow disclosure of information to states for refund offsets related to past-due state tax obligations. The amendments made by this section shall apply to refunds payable under section 6402 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 after December 31, 1998.
